item.title: Best Credit Cards for Pet Travelers (2025)
item.description:
If you travel with your dog and aren’t using hotel credit cards, you’re leaving money on the table. Pet fees, room rates, and all those extras add up fast ‚Äî but the right cards can offset most of it with points, free nights, and elite status perks.

Here’s what I use and recommend for pet travelers.

Disclosure: This post contains affiliate links. If you apply for a card through my links, I may earn a commission at no extra cost to you. See my full disclosure for details.

Jump to:

  • Why Hotel Cards Make Sense
  • The Hilton Combo

  • Marriott Alternative
  • Which Card Should You Get?

Why Hotel Cards Make Sense for Pet Owners

Most pet-friendly hotels charge $50‚Äì$150 per stay in pet fees. You can’t avoid those (yet), but you can make the room itself free by booking with points. And with elite status, you get perks like room upgrades, late checkout, and free breakfast ‚Äî all of which make traveling with a dog way easier.

I haven’t paid for a hotel room in years. I use Hilton points from my credit cards, and the free night certificates cover the rest.

My Setup: The Hilton Combo

I’m loyal to Hilton because their pet policies are solid (most properties allow dogs up to 75 lbs with no breed restrictions), and their credit cards are some of the best in the game.

üíé Hilton Honors American Express Aspire

The premium option for serious travelers.
Annual Fee $550
Status Diamond (top tier)
Sign-Up Bonus 175,000 points after $6,000 spend in 6 months
Free Nights 1/year, plus more at $30k and $60k spend

This is the card if you’re serious about hotel travel. Diamond status gets you room upgrades, executive lounge access, and late checkout ‚Äî all super helpful when traveling with a dog.

That 175,000-point bonus alone is worth around 2‚Äì3 free nights at most Hilton properties. Combined with the annual free night certificate, you could have a week’s worth of hotel stays from day one.

Key perks:

  • ‚úàÔ∏è Up to $200/year in flight credits ($50/quarter)
  • üè® Up to $400/year in Hilton resort credits ($200 every 6 months)

  • üí≥ 14x points at Hilton, 7x on dining and flights, 3x everything else

üí° Pro tip: You don’t have to book flights to use the flight credit. Buy airline gift cards or add funds to your travel bank (Delta, Southwest, etc.) ‚Äî they count toward the credit and don’t expire for 5 years. Easy way to bank the $200 even if you’re not flying soon.

How the $550 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value

Flight credits $200

Even if you only use half of these, you’re coming out ahead.

ü•á Hilton Honors American Express Surpass

Annual Fee $150
Status Gold (Diamond at $40k/year spend)
Sign-Up Bonus 155,000 points after $3,000 spend in 6 months
Free Nights 1 after $15k spend in a calendar year

This is the sweet spot for most travelers. Gold status gets you the 5th night free on award stays, plus a daily food & beverage credit or free breakfast at most properties.

The sign-up bonus is easier to hit than the Aspire ($3k vs $6k), and 155,000 points is still enough for multiple free nights.

Key perks:

  • üè® Up to $200/year in Hilton credits ($50/quarter)
  • üí≥ 12x points at Hilton, 6x on dining/groceries/gas, 3x everything else
  • üåô Free night after $15k spend

üí° Pro tip: The quarterly $50 credit works on any purchase at a Hilton property ‚Äî you don’t have to be a guest. Grab dinner or drinks at a Hilton restaurant near you, and you’ve used your credit. Do that 4 times a year and you’ve made back more than the annual fee.

How the $150 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value

Just by using the $50 quarterly credit, you’re $50 ahead before you even count the points you’re earning. If you hit the $15k spend for the free night certificate, that’s another $200+ in value.

I carry both the Aspire and Surpass. Between them, I get 2‚Äì3 free night certificates per year, plus enough points from everyday spending to cover several more nights.

If you’re just getting started, this is a no-risk way to begin earning Hilton points. You won’t get a free night certificate, but you still get the 5th night free benefit on award stays, which is a 20% discount on any points redemption of 5+ nights.

100,000 points for just $2,000 in spending ‚Äî with no annual fee ‚Äî is one of the best entry points into hotel rewards.

Key perks:

For Kimpton Travelers: IHG & Chase Cards

Kimpton has the best pet policy in the industry ‚Äî no fees, no weight limits, no breed restrictions. If that’s your priority, you’ll need IHG points (Kimpton is part of IHG).

I don’t carry these cards yet, but they’re worth considering if Kimpton is your target.

That 140,000-point bonus is enough for 2-4 free nights at most Kimptons.

Chase Ultimate Rewards points transfer 1:1 to IHG ‚Äî and to Hyatt, Marriott, and 10+ airline partners. If you don’t want to commit to one hotel chain, this is the move.

Key perks:

üí° Pro tip: If you already have Hilton cards and want to add Kimpton as an option, the Sapphire Preferred is a good complement. Transfer to IHG when you find a Kimpton you want, keep your Hilton setup for everything else.

Full breakdown: How to Book Kimpton Free with Points

The Alternative: Marriott

üè® Marriott Bonvoy Boundless

Best for Marriott loyalists.
Annual Fee $95
Status Silver Elite (Gold at $35k/year spend)
Sign-Up Bonus 3 free nights (each up to 50,000 points) after $3,000 spend in 3 months
Free Nights 1/year (up to 35,000 points, can top off with 15k more)

That sign-up bonus is huge ‚Äî 3 free nights at properties up to 50,000 points each. That could cover a long weekend at a solid Marriott property right out of the gate.

Key perks:

  • üí≥ Up to 17x points at Marriott properties
  • üçΩÔ∏è 3x on dining, groceries, and gas (first $6k/year)
  • üåô Annual free night certificate

Total $200+

The free night certificate alone is worth at least double the annual fee at most Marriott properties. You can also top it off with up to 15,000 additional points to book nicer hotels.

Marriott’s pet policies vary more by property than Hilton’s, so always check before booking. Some Marriott brands (like Residence Inn and TownePlace Suites) tend to be more consistently pet-friendly.

Which Card Should You Get?

You… Get This Why

üêï Travel 2‚Äì4x/year Hilton Surpass $200 credits > $150 fee
‚úàÔ∏è Travel frequently Hilton Aspire $1,100 in perks, Diamond upgrades
üêï‚Äçü¶∫ Have a large dog IHG Premier Kimpton has no weight limits
üîÑ Want flexibility Chase Sapphire Preferred Transfer to IHG, Hyatt, airlines
üè® Prefer Marriott Marriott Boundless 3 free nights bonus, $95 fee

How I Booked Panama City Beach for Free

For my recent 5-night trip to Panama City Beach, I used:

  • ‚úÖ Hilton points (earned from my Surpass card)
  • ‚úÖ The 5th night free benefit (book 4 nights with points, get the 5th free)

Total out of pocket for the room: $0

I still paid the $125 pet fee (5+ nights), but that’s a lot easier to stomach when the room was free.

Quick Comparison

Card Annual Fee Sign-Up Bonus Credits/Perks Free Night
üíé Hilton Aspire $550 175k points $1,100+/year Yes (annual)

üÜì Hilton (no fee) $0 100k points ‚Äî No
üè® IHG Premier $99 140k points ‚Äî Yes (annual)

üí≥ Chase Sapphire Preferred $95 60k points ‚Äî No

The Bottom Line

Pet travel gets expensive fast. The right credit cards won’t eliminate pet fees, but they can make the room free ‚Äî and that’s a huge win.

The annual fees on these cards look scary at first, but once you factor in the credits and free nights, most of them pay you back more than you put in. Start with whichever card fits your budget and travel frequency, and build from there.

I’ve been running this setup for years, and it’s saved me thousands. If you’re road tripping with your dog anyway, you might as well do it for free.

item.title: Best Credit Card Bonuses for Pet Travelers (December 2025)
item.description:
December is a great month to grab a new travel card. Several bonuses are at historic highs, and a few limited-time offers expire in January.

Here are the best credit card bonuses right now for pet travelers ‚Äî ranked by how useful they are for booking dog-friendly hotels.

üèÜ Top Pick: Hilton Surpass

Bonus: 155,000 Hilton Honors points after $3,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $150
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

This is the sweet spot for dog travelers. The 155,000-point bonus is enough for 3-5 free nights at most pet-friendly Hilton properties. You also get:

  • Automatic Gold status (80% bonus points on stays)
  • Up to $200/year in Hilton statement credits
  • 10 free nights toward Diamond status
  • Path to Diamond if you spend $40k/year

Why it’s great for pet travel: Every Hilton brand welcomes dogs with no breed restrictions, and most have no weight limits. Gold status gets you late checkout ‚Äî crucial when you need extra time for that morning dog walk.

My take: This is the card I recommend most. The bonus is high, the fee is reasonable, and Hilton’s footprint means you’ll always find a pet-friendly option.

üíé Premium Pick: Hilton Aspire

Bonus: 175,000 Hilton Honors points after $6,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $550
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

The Aspire is Hilton’s top-tier card, and 175,000 points is a solid bonus (though we’ve seen it higher). You get:

  • Automatic Diamond status (the top tier)
  • Free night certificate annually (worth up to $400+)
  • Up to $400/year in Hilton resort credits
  • Up to $200/year in airline fee credits
  • Priority Pass lounge access

Why it’s great for pet travel: Diamond status means complimentary breakfast at most properties and room upgrades when available. The free night certificate alone can offset the annual fee.

My take: Only worth it if you stay 10+ nights at Hilton annually. Otherwise, the Surpass is a better value.

üè® Best for Kimpton Lovers: IHG Premier

Bonus: 140,000 IHG One Rewards points after $3,000 spend in 3 months
Annual fee: $99

If you love Kimpton (and you should ‚Äî they’re the most dog-friendly chain), this is your card. The bonus gets you:

  • 3-4 free nights at most Kimpton properties
  • Automatic Platinum Elite status
  • Free night certificate annually (up to 40,000 points, can top up with more)
  • 4th night free on award stays

Why it’s great for pet travel: Kimpton has NO weight limits, NO pet fees, and NO breed restrictions. The 4th night free perk is huge ‚Äî book 4 nights and you’re essentially getting 25% off.

My take: If there’s a Kimpton where you travel, this card is a no-brainer. The $99 fee pays for itself with the annual free night.

üÜì Best No-Annual-Fee Option: Hilton Honors Card

Bonus: 100,000 Hilton Honors points after $2,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $0
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

New to points? Start here. 100,000 points with no annual fee is excellent for beginners. You get:

  • Automatic Silver status
  • 7x points at Hilton properties
  • 5th night free on award stays

Why it’s great for pet travel: Zero commitment, solid bonus. Use this to test whether Hilton works for your travel style before upgrading to the Surpass.

My take: Perfect first card. Grab it, hit the bonus, then decide if you want to upgrade later.

üè¢ Best for Business Owners: Hilton Business

Bonus: 175,000 Hilton Honors points after $8,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $195
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

If you have a business (even a side hustle), this is the highest Hilton bonus available right now. You get:

  • Automatic Gold status
  • Up to $240/year in Hilton credits ($60 quarterly)
  • Path to Diamond at $40k spend
  • 12x points at Hilton, 5x on other purchases

Why it’s great for pet travel: Same Hilton benefits as the personal cards, but with a bigger bonus and better earning rates on everyday spend.

üìä Quick Comparison

Card Bonus Annual Fee Best For
Hilton Surpass 155,000 pts $150 Most pet travelers
Hilton Aspire 175,000 pts $550 Frequent Hilton guests
Hilton (No Fee) 100,000 pts $0 Beginners
Hilton Business 175,000 pts $195 Business owners

January 14, 2026:

  • All Hilton Amex card bonuses (Surpass, Aspire, No-Fee, Business)

If you’ve been thinking about a Hilton card, don’t wait until the new year ‚Äî these offers could drop after the deadline.

My Recommendation

If you’re new to points: Get the no-annual-fee Hilton card. Zero risk, 100,000 points, and you can upgrade later.

If you’re ready to commit: Get the Hilton Surpass. It’s the best balance of bonus, benefits, and annual fee for pet travelers.

item.title: Why Hilton Is the Best Hotel Chain for Pet Travelers
item.description:
When I started traveling with Ansel, my 70-pound GSP/Lab mix, I quickly learned that not all hotel chains are created equal. Some properties say they’re “pet-friendly” but hit you with breed restrictions, weight limits, or fees that make you feel like your dog isn’t actually welcome.

Hilton is different. Here’s why it’s become my go-to for pet travel.

Every Hilton Brand Welcomes Dogs

This is the big one. Whether you’re staying at a Hampton Inn on a road trip or splurging on a Waldorf Astoria for a special occasion, every Hilton brand in the U.S. accepts pets.

That consistency matters when you’re planning trips with a dog. No more calling ahead to individual properties hoping they’ll say yes. No more getting turned away at check-in because someone didn’t update the website.

The brands include:

  • Hampton Inn & Suites
  • Hilton Garden Inn
  • Home2 Suites
  • Homewood Suites
  • DoubleTree
  • Embassy Suites
  • Hilton Hotels & Resorts
  • Canopy by Hilton
  • Curio Collection
  • Tapestry Collection
  • Conrad Hotels
  • Waldorf Astoria

One caveat: Weight limits vary by property, typically ranging from 50-75 lbs. If you have a larger dog, always call ahead to confirm. Check out my guide to traveling with large dogs for more tips.

Points Are Easy to Earn

Hilton points are some of the easiest hotel points to stack through everyday spending. With the right credit card, you can earn points on:

  • Groceries (including all that dog food)
  • Gas stations (road trip fuel-ups)
  • Restaurants (dog-friendly patios count!)
  • Vet bills and pet supplies
  • Everything else

I’ve booked multiple free nights at pet-friendly Hiltons without setting foot in a hotel ‚Äî just from everyday spending on my Hilton credit card.

Not sure which card is right for you? Take my quick quiz to find your perfect match.

Diamond Status Makes Pet Travel Easier

Hilton’s top-tier status, Diamond, comes with perks that are especially valuable when you’re traveling with a dog:

Room upgrades ‚Äî More space means more room for your pup to spread out. I’ve been upgraded to suites multiple times, and the extra square footage makes a huge difference with a 70-pound dog.

Late checkout ‚Äî Morning potty breaks, packing up dog gear, loading the car… it all takes longer with a pet. Late checkout (often until 2pm) gives you breathing room.

Daily food & beverage credit ‚Äî Pet fees add up. Having your meals partially covered helps offset those costs.

Executive lounge access ‚Äî A quiet spot to grab coffee or a snack, away from the chaos of the main lobby.

The best part? You don’t have to stay 60 nights a year to get Diamond. The Hilton Aspire card gives you automatic Diamond status just for having the card.

Pet Fees Are Reasonable

Hilton pet fees typically range from $50-$95 per stay, depending on the brand and location. That’s middle-of-the-road for the industry ‚Äî not the cheapest, but far from the worst offenders.

When you’re booking on points, the pet fee is often your only out-of-pocket cost. I’ll happily pay $75 for a “free” hotel stay at a property I know will welcome my dog without hassle.

My Hilton Pet Travel Stack

Here’s the setup I use for earning and booking pet-friendly Hilton stays:

  1. Hilton Aspire Card ‚Äî Automatic Diamond status, annual free night certificate, $400 resort credit
  2. Hilton Points ‚Äî Earned from everyday spending, used for free nights
  3. 5th Night Free ‚Äî Book 4 nights on points, get the 5th free (20% savings!)
  4. BringFido ‚Äî For double-checking pet policies and weight limits at specific properties

This combo has gotten me free stays at pet-friendly Embassy Suites, Hilton Garden Inns, and more ‚Äî with Ansel welcome at every single one.

Ready to Start?

If you’re new to Hilton points and want to start traveling free with your pup, here’s where to begin:

  1. Take the quiz to find the right Hilton credit card for your travel style
  2. Learn about Diamond status and why it’s worth pursuing
  3. Compare all the credit card options if you want the full breakdown

Have questions? Reach out ‚Äî I’m always happy to help fellow pet travelers figure out the points game.

item.title: Panama City Beach with My 70-Pound Dog: Embassy Suites Review
item.description:
Last month, Ansel and I made the drive from Jacksonville to Panama City Beach for a long weekend. I’d been eyeing the Embassy Suites by Hilton Panama City Beach Resort for a while ‚Äî it’s pet-friendly, right across from the beach, and I had a stack of Hilton points burning a hole in my account. Here’s how it went.

Someone approved of the room upgrade.

The Booking

I used my Hilton Honors American Express Surpass points plus a free night certificate to book this stay. I stayed for 5 nights ‚Äî and here’s a tip: when you book 4 nights with points, the 5th night is free. That’s a 20% discount built right in.

The only thing I actually paid out of pocket? Tipping the valet. That’s it.

Pet fees: $75 for stays of 1-4 nights, or $125 for 5+ nights. They allow up to 2 pets, max 75 lbs each, dogs and cats only. No breed restrictions. Ansel is a 70-pound German Shorthaired Pointer/Lab mix, so he squeaked in under the limit.

Pro tip: If you have Hilton Diamond status, request a room upgrade when you book. I asked and got bumped to a king suite with an ocean view and a balcony. Ansel spent a solid 20 minutes every morning just watching the beach from up there.

(New to points and hotel status? Check out my guide to the best credit cards for pet travelers and how Hilton Diamond status works.)

The Hotel: What You Need to Know

The Embassy Suites PCB is located right by Pier Park, across the street from the beach. Not beachfront, but close enough that it’s a 5-minute walk to sand. In fact, everything we did ‚Äî Dog Beach, Pier Park, Margaritaville ‚Äî was within walking distance of the hotel. We barely moved the car all week.

Here’s the thing nobody tells you: there’s only one elevator.

If you’re traveling with a dog ‚Äî especially a bigger one who needs to go out first thing in the morning ‚Äî request a room close to the elevator. I didn’t think to ask, and our first morning involved a very long hallway walk with an increasingly urgent pup. Lesson learned.

Making himself at home.

The room itself was spacious (it’s a suite, so you get a separate living area), clean, and the balcony was a huge win. Ansel could hang out there while I got ready without feeling cooped up.

The hotel also has designated dog areas around the property with poop bag stations, so those early morning and late night potty breaks are easy.

Note: Dogs are not allowed at the pool. If you want pool time, you’ll need to plan around it (more on that below).

The Beach

The big draw here is Dog Beach ‚Äî an exclusive dog beach right across from Pier Park. You can see the “Welcome to Dog Beach” sign from Margaritaville. It’s a short walk from the hotel.

The destination.

First time touching PCB sand.

That Gulf water is unreal.

Dog-Friendly Dining

One of the best parts of PCB is how many restaurants have dog-friendly patios ‚Äî and most of them are walking distance from the hotel. We hit up Margaritaville ‚Äî great views, Ansel got tons of attention, and they didn’t bat an eye at a 70-pound dog under the table.

Lunch with a view.

He was very well-behaved (mostly).

Exploring Pier Park

Pier Park is a huge outdoor shopping area right next to the hotel ‚Äî literally a few minutes walk. Lots of stores, restaurants, and photo ops. Ansel found his way onto a Ron Jon surfboard.

Surfer pup.

Road Trip Essentials: What I Packed

A few things that made the drive with a 70-pound dog way easier:

  • Backseat cover ‚Äî Protects the seats, gives Ansel a non-slip surface, and makes cleanup a breeze.
  • Travel water bottle with bowl ‚Äî Attaches right to a cup holder. Perfect for rest stops.
  • Poop bags ‚Äî I always overpack. Running out at a hotel is not the move.

(For my full packing list, check out road trip essentials for traveling with your dog.)

Need a Break? Daycare & Grooming Options

Sometimes you want to hit the pool or grab dinner somewhere that isn’t dog-friendly. Here are your options near the hotel:

  • ZOOMIES Pet Hotel ‚Äî Full daycare, boarding, and grooming. Book ahead, especially on weekends.
  • Dagny and Dexter’s ‚Äî Another solid daycare option nearby.
  • PetSmart in Pier Park ‚Äî Right next door for grooming or supplies. I dropped Ansel off here for a grooming session so I could spend a few hours at the pool.

I’d recommend booking daycare in advance if you know you’ll want pool time or want to explore without the dog for a day.

The Verdict

This was a genuinely easy trip. The hotel is well-located for a dog-friendly beach weekend, the points redemption felt like good value, and Ansel had a blast.

Would I go back? Yeah, probably. Next time I’ll be smarter about requesting a room near the elevator, and I’ll book daycare in advance so I can get more pool time.

Ansel’s Rating: 4/5 Paws üêæüêæüêæüêæ

What he loved: The balcony. The beach. All the new smells at Pier Park.

What he didn’t love: That long hallway walk at 6am.

Quick Reference

Detail Info
Hotel Embassy Suites by Hilton Panama City Beach Resort
Location Across from beach, next to Pier Park
Pet Policy 2 pets max, 75 lbs each, dogs/cats only, no breed restrictions
Pet Fee $75 (1-4 nights) or $125 (5+ nights)
Points Used Hilton Honors (via Surpass card + free night cert)
Out of Pocket Valet tip only

item.title: Hilton Diamond Status: How to Get It and Why It's Worth It
item.description:
Hilton Diamond is the top tier of Hilton Honors (until Diamond Reserve launches in 2026), and it comes with perks that make traveling with a dog way easier ‚Äî room upgrades, late checkout, free breakfast, and more.

Here’s how I got it and why it’s worth pursuing.

üíé How I Got Diamond Status

I earned Diamond status two ways:

First time: I hit the $40,000 spending threshold on my Hilton Surpass card through everyday spending ‚Äî groceries, gas, dining, bills. Once you hit that number, Diamond status kicks in within a few weeks.

Now: I carry the Hilton Aspire card, which gives you automatic Diamond status just for having the card. No spending threshold, no stays required ‚Äî you’re Diamond from day one.

If you’re serious about hotel travel, the Aspire is the easier path. If you’re already putting significant spend on a Surpass card, you might hit Diamond that way first.

‚≠ê Diamond Status Benefits

Here’s what you actually get:

Benefit What It Means
üõèÔ∏è Room upgrades Up to 1-bedroom suites, based on availability
üç≥ Daily food & beverage credit At U.S. properties (or free breakfast internationally)
üç∏ Executive lounge access Free breakfast, snacks, drinks (where available)
‚è∞ Late checkout Sleep in, no rush
üíØ 100% bonus points Double the base points on every stay
üåô 5th night free Book 4 nights with points, get the 5th free
üì∂ Premium WiFi Fastest speeds in the hotel
‚úÖ 48-hour room guarantee Guaranteed room if booked 48+ hours ahead
üéÅ Welcome amenities Snacks, water bottles, treats at check-in (varies by property)

üè® The Perks I Actually Use

Room Upgrades

This is the big one. As a Diamond member, I’ve been upgraded to suites multiple times ‚Äî including an ocean-view suite at the Embassy Suites in Panama City Beach. More space means more room for the dog to spread out, and a balcony is a game-changer for morning coffee while Ansel watches the beach.

Pro tip: When you book, add a note requesting an upgrade. It doesn’t guarantee anything, but it puts you on their radar.

Daily Food & Beverage Credit

At most U.S. Hilton properties, Diamond members get a daily F&B credit instead of free breakfast. The amount varies by brand (usually $15‚Äì$25 per person), and it applies to you plus one guest.

üí° Pro tip: These credits stack. Staying 3 nights? That’s 3 days of credits you can use whenever ‚Äî save them up and have a nice dinner on your last night, or use them at the bar.

Late Checkout

When you’re traveling with a dog, late checkout is clutch. No rushing to pack up and get the dog out by 11am. I’ve gotten 2pm checkout at most properties just by asking at the front desk.

Executive Lounge Access

Where available, Diamond members can access the executive lounge for free breakfast, evening appetizers, and drinks. These are more common at international properties ‚Äî in the U.S., they’re hit or miss. But when you find one, it’s a nice quiet spot to grab coffee or a snack.

Welcome Amenities

This varies by property, but I’ve received complimentary water bottles, snacks, and even treats for Ansel at check-in. Small touches that make you feel recognized.

üéØ Ways to Earn Diamond Status

Method Requirement
üí≥ Hilton Aspire card Automatic ‚Äî just have the card
üí≥ Hilton Surpass card Spend $40,000 in a calendar year
üõèÔ∏è Stays 30 stays in a calendar year
üåô Nights 60 nights in a calendar year
‚≠ê Base points Earn 120,000 base points in a calendar year

For most people, the credit card path is the easiest. Unless you’re traveling for work constantly, hitting 60 nights is tough. But everyday spending on a Surpass or Aspire card? That adds up fast.

üí≥ The Credit Card Shortcut

Hilton Aspire ($550/year)

  • Automatic Diamond status ‚Äî no spend required
  • Annual free night certificate
  • $400/year in Hilton resort credits
  • $200/year in flight credits (buy airline gift cards ‚Äî they count!)
  • 175,000 point sign-up bonus

Hilton Surpass ($150/year)

  • Gold status automatic, Diamond at $40k spend
  • $200/year in Hilton credits ($50/quarter ‚Äî use at any Hilton property, even just for dinner)
  • Free night after $15k spend
  • 155,000 point sign-up bonus

If you want Diamond without the $550 Aspire fee, the Surpass path works ‚Äî it just takes more spending. I did it for a couple years before upgrading to the Aspire.

For the full breakdown, check out my Best Credit Cards for Pet Travelers guide.

üåô Free Night Certificates: The Secret Weapon

One of my favorite Diamond perks isn’t technically a Diamond perk ‚Äî it’s the free night certificates from the Aspire card. But here’s what most people don’t realize:

These certificates work at almost any Hilton property.

I’ve used mine at resorts where rooms go for $400‚Äì$500/night. Some people have used them at properties charging $1,000+ per night. The certificate covers one standard night, regardless of the cash price.

So while you’re earning Diamond status and racking up points, those free night certificates are quietly saving you hundreds of dollars per year.

üêï Why Diamond Matters for Pet Travelers

Here’s why I think Diamond status is especially valuable when you’re traveling with a dog:

  1. Suite upgrades = more space. A regular hotel room with a 70-pound dog feels cramped. A suite with a separate living area? Much better.

  2. Late checkout = less stress. Morning potty breaks, packing up dog gear, loading the car ‚Äî it all takes longer with a pet. Late checkout gives you breathing room.

  3. F&B credits = save money. Pet fees add up. Having your meals partially covered helps offset those costs.

  4. Welcome amenities. Some properties include dog treats or pet welcome packages for Diamond members. It’s not guaranteed, but it happens.

üìÖ What’s Coming: Diamond Reserve (2026)

Hilton is adding a new tier above Diamond starting January 2026 ‚Äî Diamond Reserve. It requires 80 nights or 40 stays PLUS $18,000 in eligible spend.

The perks include confirmable suite upgrades at booking, guaranteed 4pm late checkout, and 120% bonus points. For most travelers, regular Diamond will still be the goal ‚Äî but it’s good to know what’s coming.

The good news: nothing changes for current Diamond members. All the existing benefits stay the same.

‚úÖ The Bottom Line

Diamond status makes hotel travel more comfortable ‚Äî especially with a dog. The upgrades, late checkout, and F&B credits add real value, and the credit card path makes it accessible even if you’re not a road warrior.

If you’re already staying at Hilton properties and putting spend on a Hilton card, Diamond is within reach. And once you have it, you’ll wonder how you traveled without it.

Have questions about earning or using Diamond status? Reach out ‚Äî happy to help.
